bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê pêyak ayîsiyiniw itahk êh-wa-wîkit , êh-pêyakot , nama wîhkâc wâpamêw ayîsiyiniwah , wiya pikôh êkotah êh-ayât . Once upon a time a man lived all alone and never saw any people, being all alone in that place.
kâh-nipâcih kâ-tipiskâyik , wiyâpaniyiki mâcîw . When he had slept at night, in the morning he went hunting.
wiyâpamâci mostoswah , nipahêw . Whenever he saw buffalo, he killed them.

pêyak otêyiniy otinam , êkwah pêyak opêminak , êh-kîwêt , ê-takohtêt wîkihk , êkwah manah êh-kîsitêpot , kâh-mîcisoci , êkwah ê-nikohtêt . He would take a tongue and a thigh-bone and go home, and when he reached his dwelling, he would prepare his meal, and when he had eaten, he would gather firewood.
êkosi êkwah piyisk tipiskâyiw mâna . So night would come upon him.
êkwa êy-ay-apit , piyisk kaskêyihtam êh-pêyakot . As he stayed thus by himself, at last, he felt lonesome.
êh-wâpaniyik , mîn êh-mâcît , mînah pêyak nipahêw mostoswah . When daylight came and he as usual went hunting, again he killed a buffalo.
kîwêw ; apsîs otinam kâ-mîcit . He went home; he took a little to eat.
cîk êy-ihtât wîkihk , kâ-wâpahtak mistah êh-astêyikih mihtah wîkihk . When he was near his dwelling-place, he saw a great pile of firewood by his tent.
awiyak ê-kîh-takohtêt , êkos îtêyihtam . “It must be that someone has come,” he thought. LB on {awiyak ê-kîh-takohtêt}: Short, simple speeches are often conjunct.
miywêyihtam . He was glad.
êh-pîhtokêt , nam âwiyah wâpamêw , êsah kâh-wêhpâhtakahikêyihk . When he entered, he saw nobody, though it was plain that someone had swept the place.
mihtâtam êkâh êh-wâpamât awiyah . He was sorry that he saw no one.
ay-apiw . He stayed there.
tânêhk ômah êkâ k-ôh-apit awiyak ? itêyihtam . “How is it that there is no one here?” he thought.
pôtih itah k-âpit maskisinah miskam . Lo, there where he sat, he found some moccasins.

mistahi miywêyihtam ,
iskwêw mâskôc kâ-kîh-takohtêt , êh-itêyihtahk ; He was very glad, thinking, “A woman perhaps is the one who came here.

seg.gloss: In the morning I shall hunt;

p.seg: nika-kakwêh-kêsiskawâw , mînah takohtêcih , êh-itêyihtahk . I shall try to come upon her while she is here, if she comes again,” he thought.
êh-wâpaniyik , kiyipah sipwêhtêw , êh-mâcît . At daybreak he quickly went off to hunt.
mînah nipahêw pêyak mostoswah . Again he killed a buffalo.
otêyiniy otinam êkwah ospikêkanah êkwah otihtihkosiwah êkwah opêminak . He took the tongue, the ribs, the kidneys, and a thigh bone.

êkos îsi kîwêw ,
nika-kêsiskawâw , ê-itêyihtah . Then he went home, thinking, “I shall come in time to find her there.”
pâh-pimipahtâw . He kept running.
cîk êy-ihtât wîkihk , wâpahtam êh-pikihcêsiyik , mînah mistahi mistah êh-astêyikih . When he got near his dwelling, he saw a little smoke, and a great pile of firewood.
êh-pîhtokêt , iyâyaw nanâtawâpiw : nam âwiyah wâpamêw . When he entered, eagerly he looked about: he saw no one.
mistahi mihtâtam êkâ h-apiyit awiyah . He was very sorry that no one was there.
êkwah ê-paminawasot , kîtahtawê kâ-miskahk maskisinah . Then, as he went about his cooking, soon he found some moccasins.
otinam , êh-wâ-wâpahtahk , êh-miywâsiniyikih . He picked them up and examined them; they were very pretty.
mâskôc iskwêw kâ-tâh-takosihk , itêyihtam ; “Probably it is a woman has been coming here,” he thought;

seg.gloss: “Now all the harder I shall try to find her here.

p.seg: kîkisêpâ nika-sipwêhtân , êkosi itêyihtam . Early in the morning I shall go,” he thought.
tâpwêh ê-kîh-mîcisot kawisimôw êh-nipât . After eating he lay down to sleep.
namoya mîcisôw , ê-sipwêhtêt , ê-mâcît . without eating he went forth to hunt.
pôtih kiyipah nipahêw mostoswah . In a short time he killed a buffalo,
êkwah ê-kîh-wiyinihât , ospikêkanah otihtihkosiwah otinam , êh-ati-kîwêt . and when he had cut it up, took the ribs and the kidneys and went home.
pâh-pimipahtâw . He ran as he went.
cîk êy-ihtât wîkihk , kâ-wâpahtahk mistah a-pikihtêyik wîkih . When he saw close to his dwelling, he saw much smoke rising from his tent.

mistahi miywêyihtam ,
mâskôc apiw , ê-têyihtah . He was very glad, thinking, “Perhaps she is there.”
êh-takohtêt , ê-pîhtokêt , awîn ôhih kîh-apiyiwah mistahi êh-miyosiyit iskwêwah ôhtapiwinihk . When he got there and entered, lo and behold, there sat a very handsome woman on his settee.
êkotah nahapiw , ê-wîh-pâhpihikot , ê-kitâpamât . He sat down there, and she smiled at him as he looked at her.
sâsay êsah kâh-paminawasôyit . It appeared that she had already done the cooking.

sêmâk otinamiyiwah omaskisinah , ê-kêtaskisinênikot , kotakah ê-wîh-postaskisinahikot , êkwah ê-kâsîcihcênikot , êh-kâsîhkwênikot . Without delay she took off his moccasins and put others on his feet, and she washed his hands and face.
êkosi êkwah asamik ; êkwah mîcisowak . Thereupon she gave him to eat, and they took their meal.
â , mistahi miywêyihtam . Oh, he was very glad.

ômis îtêw aw îskwêw :
tânikhih apisîs kâ-pêtâyan wiyâs ? Thus spoke that woman: “Why do you bring so little meat?”

âh , itwêw awa nâpêw ,
nam âwiyak ntihtatêyimâw ; “Oh,” said the man, “I did not think anyone was here;
êyak ôhci apisîs k-ôh-pêtâyân , êkosi itwêw awa nâpêw ; that is why I brought only a little,” he said;
tântêh mâk ômah êy-ohtohtêyin ? itwêw awa nâpêw . “But whence do you come?” he asked.
wâhyaw ôtêh êh-wîkiyâhk , itwêw aw îskwêw ; “A long ways from here we dwell,” she answered.

seg.gloss: “Please, when you hunt, bring much meat;

p.seg:
nôhtêhkatêwak , itwêw aw îskwêw ,
nôhtâwiy , itwêw . they are in want of food,” she said, “my father and his people.”
êhag , itwêw awa nâpêw . “Very well,” said he.
êkotah ohci tahto-kîsikâw mâcîw . So he hunted every day.
piyisk mistahi nipahêw mostoswah . In time he killed many buffalo.
awa iskwêw mistah âtoskêw , wiyâsah êy-osihtât . The woman worked a great deal, preparing the food.

mistah êh-ayâcik ,
nawac itohtêyahk nôhtâwiy , itwêw awa iskwêw ; When they had a large amount of it, “Suppose we go to my father's place,” said the woman;
êhag , itwêw awa nâpêw . “Very well,” said the man.
wâpahkih , itwêw aw îskwêw . “Tomorrow,” she said.

seg.gloss: “But what are we to use to carry things?”

p.seg: âh , tit-êhtakon êtokê tânisi t-êsi-pihkohoyahk , itwêw aw îskwêw . “Oh, there will be some way we can manage,” she answered.

tâpwê kîksêpâ êh-mîcisocik ,
nîkânohtêhkan , itêw owîkimâkanah ; Then, when they ate in the morning, “Go on ahead,” she told her husband;

itâp mistikwah ka-cimatân , êkotah ta-kapêsiyahk ; êkotah ohci ka-mâcîn , itêw aw îskwêw onâpêmah . “Then you will set up some sticks at the place where we are to camp; from that place you will go hunting,” she said to her husband.
tâpwê ê-kîsi-mîcisocik sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw . So, when they had eaten, the man set out.
êkwah aw îskwêw wawêyîw , ôhi ocayânisiwâwah onîmâwiniwâwah nâh-nâway êh-astât . And the woman made ready, laying their belongings and their food supply in a row.
êkwah ê-kîsi-wawêyît aw îskwêw atih-tâh-têhci-tahkoskêw onîmâwiniwâwah ; Then, when she had got ready, she went along, stepping each time upon their bundles of food;
êkosi êh-ati-sipwêhtêt , nama kêkway ihtakoniyiwah ôhôw onîmâwiniwâwa . and when in this wise she set out, not a trace was there of their supplies of food.
êkos îs êh-pah-pimohtêt . So then she walked on.
itêh êh-otâkosiniyik kâ-miskahk mistikwah êh-cimatêyikih , êkotah kapêsiw . Toward nightfall she found the sticks that were set up in the ground; there she made camp.
êkwah ê-tahkiskâcikêt aw îskwêw , wîkiwâw êkotah astêyiw . When she kicked the ground, there lay their tent.
êkwah otinam , êh-mânokêt . Then she took the tent and set it up.
êh-kîsi-mânokêt , pîhcâyihk âsay mîna tahkiskâcikêw ; When she had set it up, inside again she stamped the ground;
kahkiyaw êkotê pahkihtiniyiwa ocayânisiwâwah onîmâwiniwâwa . on that spot fell all their belongings and their supplies of food.
êkosi êkwah pîhtokêw aw îskwêw , êh-paminawasot . Then she went inside and cooked their meal.

pôtih êh-ati-kîwêt awa nâpêw , kâ-wâpahtahk wîkiwâw ,
tânisi tiyôtahk ? êy-itêyimât owîkimâkanah . There, when the man came back and saw their dwelling, “How did she do it?” he thought concerning his wife.
êh-pîhtokêt , kâ-wîh-pâhpihikot owîkimâkanah . When he entered, there saw was, smiling at him.
êh-itâpit , kahkiyaw wâpahtam ocayânisiwâwa onîmâwiniwâwa . He looked about and saw all their belongings and their supplies of food.
mistahi mâmaskâtam êh-tôtamiyit . He wondered greatly at what she had done.

ômis îtwêw awa aw îskwêw :
wâpahkih ka-takohtânânaw itah nôhtâwiy k-âyâcik . Thus spoke she: “Tomorrow we shall come to where my father's people stay.
mistahi nôhtêhkatêwak , itwêw awa iskwêw . They are in great want of food,” she said.
tâpwêh êh-wâpahk , kîksêpâ waniskâwak . So when day broke, early they arose.
ê-kîh-mîcisocik , wawêyîwak . When they had eaten, they made ready.
wîciwôhkamawin , itwêw aw îskwêw ; “Help me,” said the woman; LB on {wîciwôhkamawin}: Error or real variant? The usual form would be {wîcôhkamawin}.
tânisih êh-tôtahk ? k-êtêyihtaman , ka-kiskêyihtên tânsih êh-tôtamân , itwêw away iskwêw . “Since you have been thinking, ‘How does she do it?’ you shall now know how I do,” she said.
hâhag , itwêw awa nâpêw . “Yes,” answered the man.
tâpwê wawêyîwak , nâh-nâway êh-astâcik ocayânisiwâwa onîmâwiniwâwa . Accordingly they made ready by laying in a row their possessions and their stored meats.

êh-kitâpamât owîkimâkanah , êh-atih-sipwêhtêyit , êh-tah-têhci-tahkoskêyit onîmâwiniwâwah , nama kêkway wâpahtam awa nâpêw . When he watched his wife, as she went forth and stepped on one after another of their bundles, he saw nothing at all there.
êkos îsi pimohtêcik , mistahi mâmaskâtêw owîkimâkanah , êh-tôtamiyit . So as they walked on, he marvelled greatly at what his wife had done.

êkos îsi ê-pa-pimohtêcik , kîtahtawê , êh-at-ôtâkosiniyik , kâ-wâpahtahkik êh-pikihtêyik itah êh-pasahcâyik , ê-sakâyik ; Then, as they walked on, towards evening they saw smoke rising from a wooded ravine;
êkotah ê-sâkêwêcik , kâ-pê-mâtâwisiyit osîmisah aw îskwêw . when they came in sight of that place, the woman's younger sister came forth.

ômisi itwêyiwah :
âyêyi , misi-pêtâw nîmâwinah nimis ! itwêyiwah . She cried: “Splendid! My elder sister is bringing a great store of meat!”
êkos âti-takohtêwak wîkiyihk . So they went on and came to the house.

awa kisêyiniw ,
hay hay hay ! matwê-itwêw . The old man called out, “Splendid!”

ê-yôhtênahk aw îskwêw , êh-pîhtokê-tah-tahkiskâcikêt , pîhcâyihk pahkihtiniyiwah onîmâwiniwâwa ocayânisiwâwa . When the woman opened the door and, as she entered, stamped repeatedly, then into the lodge fell their stored meats and their belongings.

êkosi awah nôtokêsiw êh-at-ôtinahk , mistahi miywêyihtam ,
êkwah kê-mîcisoyân , êh-itêyihtah . Then when the old woman went on to pick them up, she greatly rejoiced, thinking, “So now I shall eat.”
nanâskomôw awa kisêyiniw . The old man gave thanks:
êkosi pîhtokêwak . [no translation given]

ômis îtwêw awa kisêyiniw :
êkosi ê-kîh-itêyihtamân , ntânis ,
itohtê ! kâ-kîh-ititân ,
êh-pa-pêyakot ninahâhkisîm , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . “Thus I had it in mind, daughter, when ‘Go there,’ I said to you, ‘where my son-in-law dwells alone,’” said the old man.
êkotah ay-ayâw êkwah . There he stayed then.

pâtih kinwêsk ê-kîh-ayât êkotah , êkwah ê-miyoskamiyik , kâ-kiskêyihtahk wâkayôsah kâ-wîwit ôh îskwêwah k-êtêyihtahk , ôhi mînah kisêyiniwah nôtokêsiwah wâkayôsah ês ôhi . When he had been there a long time, and spring had come, then he knew that she, the woman, as it seemed to him, whom he had to wife, was a bear, and that also the old man and the old woman were bears.
êkwah mihtâtam êkâ tahkih ta-kîh-wîcêwât . And he was sorry that he could not always be with them.
êkosi êkoyikohk êwakô âtayôhkêwin . That is the end of this sacred story.
